metadata.title: ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡•á ‡§ò‡§∞ (House of Words)
metadata.subject: Marathi
metadata.description: This chapter marks the beginning of Part 2 (‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó-‡•®) of the textbook and focuses on vocabulary building. Words are compared to a house with many rooms ‚Äî each word has multiple meanings, related forms, and connections to other words. The chapter covers word families (‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§ï‡•Å‡§ü‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¨), synonyms (‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶), antonyms (‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶), words with multiple meanings (‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶), and introduces students to the Marathi dictionary (‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§ï‡•ã‡§∂). Activities in this chapter help students explore the rich vocabulary of the Marathi language.

preAssessment.question: The Marathi word '‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶' (Samanarthi Shabd) refers to:

options.C: Words that sound the same but have different meanings

preAssessment.question: What is the Marathi term for antonyms (words with opposite meanings)?
Which of the following is a synonym (‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä) of the Marathi word '‡§ò‡§∞' (home/house)?

options.A: Words that are synonyms of each other
options.B: Words from a common root (word family)
options.C: A single word that has many different meanings

preAssessment.question: What is the Marathi word for 'dictionary'?

concepts.title: What is a Word Family? (‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§ï‡•Å‡§ü‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¨)
concepts.content: A word family (‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§ï‡•Å‡§ü‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¨) is a group of words that are related because they come from the same root word (‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≥ ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶). Just like a family has parents, children, and relatives ‚Äî a word family has a root word and many derived forms. For example, the root '‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ' (learning/knowledge) gives rise to a whole family: ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä (student), ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ø (school), ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§® (learned/scholar), ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ø (college), ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•Ä‡§† (university). Understanding word families helps students guess the meaning of new words and greatly expands Marathi vocabulary.
keyPoints: ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§ï‡•Å‡§ü‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¨ = word family ‚Äî all words derived from the same root (‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≥ ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶).
Knowing root words helps understand the meaning of related words without a dictionary.
Sanskrit roots are very common in Marathi ‚Äî understanding them unlocks many Marathi words.
Building word families in vocabulary practice is an effective way to learn Marathi.
concepts.funFact: Marathi is closely related to Sanskrit ‚Äî about 50% of Marathi vocabulary comes directly from Sanskrit! This means that if you know a Sanskrit root word, you can often guess the meaning of many Marathi words. For example, '‡§®‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞' in Marathi comes from Sanskrit '‡§®‡§Æ‡§∏' (bow) + '‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞' (act of) ‚Äî 'the act of bowing in respect!'
concepts.textbookRef: Chapter 8, Pages 27-28 ‚Äî Maharashtra Board 7th Grade Marathi (Second Language)

concepts.title: Synonyms in Marathi (‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶)
concepts.content: Synonyms (‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶) are words that have the same or very similar meanings. '‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®' means same/similar, '‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•' means meaning ‚Äî so ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä = having the same meaning. Having synonyms is very important for good writing ‚Äî using different words for the same thing makes writing more interesting and varied. In Marathi, synonyms often come from different origins (Sanskrit, Prakrit, Apabhramsha, regional dialects), which gives writers a choice of formal and informal words for the same thing. Example: Water = ‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä (common/informal), ‡§ú‡§≤ (formal/Sanskrit), ‡§®‡•Ä‡§∞ (poetic), ‡§â‡§¶‡§ï (archaic/religious).

examples.text: Happy: ‡§Ü‡§®‡§Ç‡§¶‡•Ä, ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡•Ä, ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§®, ‡§ñ‡•Ç‡§∂ ‚Äî all mean happy, with slight differences in formality and nuance.

keyPoints: ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶ = synonyms ‚Äî words with the same or similar meanings.
Marathi has many synonyms because words come from Sanskrit, Prakrit, and regional dialects.
Using synonyms in writing makes the language richer and avoids boring repetition.
Synonyms can differ in formality: ‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä (everyday), ‡§ú‡§≤ (formal) ‚Äî same meaning, different register.
Learning synonyms expands vocabulary and helps understand formal Marathi texts.
concepts.funFact: The Marathi word for elephant has many synonyms because elephants were considered royal and sacred: ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä (common), ‡§ó‡§ú (poetic/formal), ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§™ (Sanskrit ‚Äî two-drinker, because elephants drink with trunk and mouth), ‡§®‡§æ‡§ó (also means elephant in some contexts ‚Äî same as snake, showing word complexity!). Marathi poetry loves using the rare and beautiful synonyms!

concepts.title: Antonyms in Marathi (‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶)
concepts.content: Antonyms (‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶) are words with opposite meanings. '‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß' means opposite, '‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•' means meaning ‚Äî so ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä = having opposite meaning. Understanding antonyms helps students think about concepts and their opposites, which is important for logical thinking and writing. In Marathi, many antonyms are formed by: (1) Adding the prefix '‡§Ö-' (making it negative): ‡§∏‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¶‡§∞ ‚Üí ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¶‡§∞, ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§® ‚Üí ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®. (2) Completely different words: ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§†‡§æ (big) ‚Üí ‡§≤‡§π‡§æ‡§® (small). Key antonym pairs: ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§†‡§æ/‡§≤‡§π‡§æ‡§®, ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≥‡§æ/‡§™‡§æ‡§Ç‡§¢‡§∞‡§æ, ‡§â‡§ú‡•á‡§°/‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞, ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ/‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ, ‡§Ü‡§®‡§Ç‡§¶/‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ, ‡§ú‡§°/‡§π‡§≤‡§ï‡§æ, ‡§ú‡•Å‡§®‡§æ/‡§®‡§µ‡§æ.
keyPoints: ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶ = antonyms ‚Äî words with opposite meanings.
Method 1: Add prefix '‡§Ö-' to make a negative: ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‚Üí ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø ‚Üí ‡§Ö‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø.
Method 2: Completely different antonym words: ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§†‡§æ ‚Üî ‡§≤‡§π‡§æ‡§®, ‡§ú‡•Å‡§®‡§æ ‚Üî ‡§®‡§µ‡§æ.
Learning antonyms in pairs is an effective way to double your Marathi vocabulary!
concepts.funFact: In Marathi literature and proverbs (‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§£‡•Ä), antonyms are used for beautiful effect. '‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ-‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ' (joy-sorrow) is used together so often it has become a compound: '‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§®‡§æ‡§ö‡•á ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ-‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ' means the joys and sorrows of life. Pairing opposites to show the full range of an experience is a classic Marathi literary technique!

concepts.title: Words with Multiple Meanings (‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶)
concepts.content: ‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶ (Anekarthi Shabd) are single words that have multiple different meanings ‚Äî the context tells you which meaning is intended. '‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§ï' means many, '‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•' means meaning. These words can be tricky for learners because the same word can mean completely different things! Examples: '‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•' itself means (1) meaning/definition AND (2) money/wealth. '‡§ï‡§æ‡§®' means (1) ear AND (2) the letter-marker '‡§æ' in Marathi script. '‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞' means (1) arrow AND (2) riverbank/shore. '‡§®‡§æ‡§ó' means (1) cobra/snake AND (2) elephant (in classical poetry). Understanding context is key.

examples.text: '‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•': (1) meaning/definition (‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§• ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø? = What is the meaning of this?) (2) money/wealth (‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ = economics).
'‡§ï‡§æ‡§®': (1) ear (‡§ï‡§æ‡§® ‡§∏‡§æ‡§´ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ = clean your ears) (2) the Marathi vowel marker '‡§æ' (the 'aa' kaana).
'‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞': (1) arrow (‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§®‡•á ‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§≤‡§æ = Shivaji shot an arrow) (2) riverbank (‡§®‡§¶‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ ‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞ = river bank).
'‡§™‡§æ‡§®': (1) leaf of a tree (‡§ù‡§æ‡§°‡§æ‡§ö‡•á ‡§™‡§æ‡§® = tree leaf) (2) betel leaf for eating (‡§™‡§æ‡§® ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§£‡•á = eating betel).

keyPoints: ‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶ = words with multiple meanings ‚Äî context determines which meaning is intended.
Important examples: ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§• (meaning/money), ‡§ï‡§æ‡§® (ear/kaana marker), ‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞ (arrow/riverbank), ‡§™‡§æ‡§® (leaf/betel).
Reading the full sentence context always helps determine which meaning is correct.
These words are common in Marathi riddles (‡§ï‡•ã‡§°‡•Ä) and wordplay ‚Äî poets love them!
Marathi dictionaries (‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§ï‡•ã‡§∂) list all the different meanings of ‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä words.
concepts.funFact: The Marathi word '‡§Æ‡•ã‡§∞' can mean peacock (the bird) ‚Äî but in certain dialects and older texts, it can also refer to a specific type of pot or vessel! Similarly, the word '‡§π‡§æ‡§∞' means (1) a garland/necklace AND (2) defeat. So '‡§π‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ò‡§æ‡§≤‡§£‡•á' = to put a garland on someone (honour), but '‡§π‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§£‡•á' = to accept defeat! Same word, wildly different meanings!

concepts.title: Using a Marathi Dictionary (‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§ï‡•ã‡§∂)
concepts.content: A Marathi dictionary (‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§ï‡•ã‡§∂) is an essential tool for any student of the language. '‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶' = word, '‡§ï‡•ã‡§∂' = treasury/store ‚Äî so ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§ï‡•ã‡§∂ literally means 'treasury of words.' Marathi dictionaries are arranged alphabetically (‡§Ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡•á) according to the Marathi alphabet (‡§Ö, ‡§Ü, ‡§á, ‡§à, ‡§â, ‡§ä, ‡§è, ‡§ê, ‡§ì, ‡§î, ‡§ï, ‡§ñ, ‡§ó...). Each entry gives: the word, its pronunciation/spelling, its grammatical category (noun, verb, etc.), its meaning(s), and sometimes examples of usage. Famous Marathi dictionaries include: Molesworth's Marathi-English Dictionary (1831 ‚Äî still used by scholars) and the Marathi Vishwakosh (Maharashtra's Encyclopaedia).

examples.text: Marathi dictionaries are arranged ‡§Ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡•á (alphabetically) ‚Äî starting with ‡§Ö and going through the full alphabet.
Dictionary entries show: word ‚Üí category (‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ/‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§¶ etc.) ‚Üí meaning(s) ‚Üí usage examples.
Online Marathi dictionaries are now available ‚Äî shabdakosh.com is a popular free Marathi dictionary website.
J.T. Molesworth's 1831 Marathi-English dictionary has 20,000+ words and is still a scholarly reference!

keyPoints: ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§ï‡•ã‡§∂ = dictionary; ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶ (word) + ‡§ï‡•ã‡§∂ (treasury) = 'treasury of words.'
Marathi dictionaries are arranged ‡§Ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡•á ‚Äî alphabetically following the Devanagari alphabet order.
A dictionary entry gives: spelling, pronunciation, grammatical category, meanings, and examples.
Famous Marathi dictionaries: Molesworth (1831), Maharashtra Government's Marathi Vishwakosh.
Learning to use a Marathi dictionary is an important skill ‚Äî it makes you independent in learning.
concepts.funFact: The largest Marathi reference work is the '‡§Æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§†‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•ã‡§∂' (Marathi Encyclopaedia) ‚Äî a 20-volume work published by the Maharashtra Government that covers everything from history and science to culture and geography in the Marathi language. It is one of the most comprehensive encyclopaedias in any Indian language!

test.question: What does '‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶' mean?

options.B: Words with the same or similar meanings (synonyms)
options.C: Words that belong to the same word family

test.explanation: '‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä' = ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§® (same/equal) + ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§• (meaning) ‚Äî so synonyms are words with the same or similar meanings. For example: ‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä and ‡§ú‡§≤ are ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä (both mean water). '‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä' = antonyms (opposite), '‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä' = multiple meanings, '‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§ï‡•Å‡§ü‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¨' = word family.

test.question: Which of these is an antonym (‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä) of '‡§â‡§ú‡•á‡§°' (light)?
test.explanation: '‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞' means darkness ‚Äî the opposite (‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä) of ‡§â‡§ú‡•á‡§° (light). '‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂' means light/brightness (synonym of ‡§â‡§ú‡•á‡§°, not antonym). '‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ' means lamp. '‡§ö‡§Æ‡§ï' means shine/sparkle.

test.question: The Marathi word '‡§™‡§æ‡§®' (paan) is an example of '‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶' because it means:

options.B: Both a tree leaf AND a betel leaf

test.explanation: '‡§™‡§æ‡§®' is an ‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶ (word with multiple meanings): (1) ‡§™‡§æ‡§® = leaf of a tree (‡§ù‡§æ‡§°‡§æ‡§ö‡•á ‡§™‡§æ‡§®); (2) ‡§™‡§æ‡§® = betel leaf used for eating (‡§µ‡§ø‡§°‡§æ/‡§™‡§æ‡§® ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§£‡•á). Context tells you which meaning is intended. In a poem about a tree, '‡§™‡§æ‡§®' = leaf; in a reference to someone chewing, '‡§™‡§æ‡§®' = betel leaf.

test.question: The root word '‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ' (knowledge) belongs to a word family. Which of these is NOT a member of this word family?
test.explanation: '‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§Ø' (victory) comes from a completely different root ‚Äî '‡§ú‡§Ø' (victory/win). It is not related to '‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ' (knowledge). The ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ word family includes: ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä (student ‚Äî 'seeker of knowledge'), ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ø (school ‚Äî 'place of knowledge'), ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§® (scholar ‚Äî 'one with knowledge'), ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•Ä‡§† (university).

test.question: What is the Marathi word '‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§ï‡•ã‡§∂' made up of?
test.explanation: '‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§ï‡•ã‡§∂' = ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶ (word) + ‡§ï‡•ã‡§∂ (treasury/store). It literally means 'treasury of words' ‚Äî a perfect description of a dictionary, which stores and preserves the meanings of all words. '‡§ï‡•ã‡§∂' also means 'womb' in Sanskrit (suggesting something that holds and nourishes), which is poetically fitting for a dictionary.

test.question: Which of the following is a synonym (‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä) of '‡§Ü‡§®‡§Ç‡§¶' (happiness/joy)?
test.explanation: '‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ' (pleasure/happiness/well-being) is a ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä (synonym) of '‡§Ü‡§®‡§Ç‡§¶' (joy/happiness) ‚Äî both express positive emotional states. '‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ' is the antonym (opposite), '‡§≠‡•Ä‡§§‡•Ä' = fear, and '‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó' = anger are completely different emotions.

test.question: In which order are words arranged in a Marathi dictionary (‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§ï‡•ã‡§∂)?

options.C: Alphabetically (‡§Ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡•á) according to the Devanagari alphabet
options.D: By the last letter of the word

test.explanation: Marathi dictionaries are arranged '‡§Ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡•á' ‚Äî alphabetically according to the Devanagari alphabet, starting with ‡§Ö, ‡§Ü, ‡§á, ‡§à, ‡§â, ‡§ä, then consonants: ‡§ï, ‡§ñ, ‡§ó, ‡§ò... This is the same system used in most Indian language dictionaries. Knowing the Marathi alphabet order is essential for using a dictionary.

test.question: The prefix '‡§Ö-' in Marathi creates which type of words?
test.explanation: Adding '‡§Ö-' prefix to a Marathi word creates its antonym (opposite) by making it negative. Examples: ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø (truth) ‚Üí ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø (untruth/lie), ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§® (knowledge) ‚Üí ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§® (ignorance), ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø (possible) ‚Üí ‡§Ö‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø (impossible), ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§• (healthy) ‚Üí ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§• (unwell/uneasy).

test.question: The Marathi word '‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞' (teer) is an ‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶ because it means both:
test.explanation: '‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞' is an ‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶ (multiple meanings): (1) ‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞ = arrow (used in '‡§ß‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¨‡§æ‡§£/‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡•á' = to shoot an arrow); (2) ‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞ = riverbank or shore (used in '‡§®‡§¶‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ ‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞' = the bank of a river). Context always determines which meaning is intended.

test.question: In the metaphor of this chapter's title '‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡•á ‡§ò‡§∞' (House of Words), what does the 'house with many rooms' represent?

options.A: The classroom where Marathi is taught
options.B: The many meanings, related words, synonyms, and antonyms that a word connects to
options.C: A physical building where dictionaries are stored
options.D: The teacher's house full of books

test.explanation: The metaphor '‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡•á ‡§ò‡§∞' (House of Words) compares a word to a house with many rooms. Each 'room' represents a different aspect of the word: its synonyms, antonyms, related words (word family), and multiple meanings. Just as a house has many rooms, each word has many dimensions of meaning and connection.

keyConcepts: ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§ï‡•Å‡§ü‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¨ = word family ‚Äî words from the same root
commonMisconceptions: Students often confuse ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä (synonyms) and ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä (antonyms) ‚Äî memorize: ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§® = same, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß = opposite.
Not all '‡§Ö-' prefix words are antonyms formed from their base ‚Äî '‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ó‡§£' (courtyard) has nothing to do with a negative prefix!
Students may think synonyms are perfectly interchangeable ‚Äî they have similar but often slightly different meanings and registers (formal vs informal).

‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶ are sometimes confused with ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§ï‡•Å‡§ü‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¨ ‚Äî in a word family, words are related in meaning; in ‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä, ONE word has MULTIPLE unrelated meanings.
realWorldExamples: Online Marathi dictionary: shabdakosh.com provides free Marathi word meanings, synonyms, and translations.
Maharashtra Government's Marathi Vishwakosh (Encyclopedia) ‚Äî 20 volumes, available in libraries across Maharashtra.
Pune's Balbharati (Maharashtra State Bureau of Textbook Production) ‚Äî the organization that publishes school textbooks, also produces vocabulary resources.
Marathi newspapers like Loksatta, Maharashtra Times, Sakal ‚Äî reading newspapers regularly builds vocabulary organically.

interactiveElement.title: Unscramble the Word!
interactiveElement.description: Rearrange the letters to form the correct Marathi vocabulary word.

textbookExercise.instructions: Memorize these exam-style answers to maximize scoring in textbook-focused assessments.

qaCards.question: What does '‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶' mean?
qaCards.answer: '‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä' = ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§® (same/equal) + ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§• (meaning) ‚Äî so synonyms are words with the same or similar meanings. For example: ‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä and ‡§ú‡§≤ are ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä (both mean water). '‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä' = antonyms (opposite), '‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä' = multiple meanings, '‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§ï‡•Å‡§ü‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¨' = word family.

qaCards.question: Which of these is an antonym (‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä) of '‡§â‡§ú‡•á‡§°' (light)?
qaCards.answer: '‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞' means darkness ‚Äî the opposite (‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä) of ‡§â‡§ú‡•á‡§° (light). '‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂' means light/brightness (synonym of ‡§â‡§ú‡•á‡§°, not antonym). '‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ' means lamp. '‡§ö‡§Æ‡§ï' means shine/sparkle.

qaCards.question: The Marathi word '‡§™‡§æ‡§®' (paan) is an example of '‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶' because it means:
qaCards.answer: '‡§™‡§æ‡§®' is an ‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶ (word with multiple meanings): (1) ‡§™‡§æ‡§® = leaf of a tree (‡§ù‡§æ‡§°‡§æ‡§ö‡•á ‡§™‡§æ‡§®); (2) ‡§™‡§æ‡§® = betel leaf used for eating (‡§µ‡§ø‡§°‡§æ/‡§™‡§æ‡§® ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§£‡•á). Context tells you which meaning is intended. In a poem about a tree, '‡§™‡§æ‡§®' = leaf; in a reference to someone chewing, '‡§™‡§æ‡§®' = betel leaf.

qaCards.question: The root word '‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ' (knowledge) belongs to a word family. Which of these is NOT a member of this word family?
qaCards.answer: '‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§Ø' (victory) comes from a completely different root ‚Äî '‡§ú‡§Ø' (victory/win). It is not related to '‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ' (knowledge). The ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ word family includes: ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä (student ‚Äî 'seeker of knowledge'), ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ø (school ‚Äî 'place of knowledge'), ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§® (scholar ‚Äî 'one with knowledge'), ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•Ä‡§† (university).

qaCards.question: What is the Marathi word '‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§ï‡•ã‡§∂' made up of?
qaCards.answer: '‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§ï‡•ã‡§∂' = ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶ (word) + ‡§ï‡•ã‡§∂ (treasury/store). It literally means 'treasury of words' ‚Äî a perfect description of a dictionary, which stores and preserves the meanings of all words. '‡§ï‡•ã‡§∂' also means 'womb' in Sanskrit (suggesting something that holds and nourishes), which is poetically fitting for a dictionary.

qaCards.question: Which of the following is a synonym (‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä) of '‡§Ü‡§®‡§Ç‡§¶' (happiness/joy)?
qaCards.answer: '‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ' (pleasure/happiness/well-being) is a ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä (synonym) of '‡§Ü‡§®‡§Ç‡§¶' (joy/happiness) ‚Äî both express positive emotional states. '‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ' is the antonym (opposite), '‡§≠‡•Ä‡§§‡•Ä' = fear, and '‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó' = anger are completely different emotions.

qaCards.question: In which order are words arranged in a Marathi dictionary (‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§ï‡•ã‡§∂)?
qaCards.answer: Marathi dictionaries are arranged '‡§Ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡•á' ‚Äî alphabetically according to the Devanagari alphabet, starting with ‡§Ö, ‡§Ü, ‡§á, ‡§à, ‡§â, ‡§ä, then consonants: ‡§ï, ‡§ñ, ‡§ó, ‡§ò... This is the same system used in most Indian language dictionaries. Knowing the Marathi alphabet order is essential for using a dictionary.

qaCards.question: The prefix '‡§Ö-' in Marathi creates which type of words?
qaCards.answer: Adding '‡§Ö-' prefix to a Marathi word creates its antonym (opposite) by making it negative. Examples: ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø (truth) ‚Üí ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø (untruth/lie), ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§® (knowledge) ‚Üí ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§® (ignorance), ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø (possible) ‚Üí ‡§Ö‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø (impossible), ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§• (healthy) ‚Üí ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§• (unwell/uneasy).

qaCards.question: The Marathi word '‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞' (teer) is an ‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶ because it means both:
qaCards.answer: '‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞' is an ‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶ (multiple meanings): (1) ‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞ = arrow (used in '‡§ß‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¨‡§æ‡§£/‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡•á' = to shoot an arrow); (2) ‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞ = riverbank or shore (used in '‡§®‡§¶‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ ‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞' = the bank of a river). Context always determines which meaning is intended.

qaCards.question: In the metaphor of this chapter's title '‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡•á ‡§ò‡§∞' (House of Words), what does the 'house with many rooms' represent?
qaCards.answer: The metaphor '‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡•á ‡§ò‡§∞' (House of Words) compares a word to a house with many rooms. Each 'room' represents a different aspect of the word: its synonyms, antonyms, related words (word family), and multiple meanings. Just as a house has many rooms, each word has many dimensions of meaning and connection.

longAnswers.question: What does '‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶' mean? Explain with examples.
longAnswers.modelAnswer: '‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä' means having the same or similar meaning, formed by combining '‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®' (same) and '‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•' (meaning). Using synonyms makes the Marathi language richer and avoids boring repetition in writing. Marathi has many synonyms because words come from various origins like Sanskrit, Prakrit, and regional dialects. For example, the word for water can be '‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä' (informal) or '‡§ú‡§≤' (formal). Learning synonyms expands your vocabulary and helps understand formal texts.
keyPoints: ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä means having the same or similar meaning.
Synonyms make writing richer and avoid repetition.
Marathi synonyms originate from Sanskrit, Prakrit, and dialects.
Examples include ‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä/‡§ú‡§≤ for water and ‡§ò‡§∞/‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏ for house.

longAnswers.question: What is the Marathi word '‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§ï‡•ã‡§∂' made up of and how is it used?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: The Marathi word '‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§ï‡•ã‡§∂' is made up of two words: '‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶' meaning word, and '‡§ï‡•ã‡§∂' meaning treasury or store, translating literally to 'treasury of words'. A dictionary is an essential tool arranged alphabetically (‡§Ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡•á) according to the Devanagari alphabet. It provides the spelling, pronunciation, grammatical category, meaning, and usage examples for words. Famous dictionaries include Molesworth's 1831 dictionary and the Marathi Vishwakosh.
keyPoints: ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§ï‡•ã‡§∂ literally means 'treasury of words'.
Words are arranged alphabetically (‡§Ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡•á) using the Devanagari script.
It provides meanings, pronunciation, grammatical categories, and examples.
It makes students independent in learning new Marathi vocabulary.

longAnswers.question: In the metaphor of this chapter's title '‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡•á ‡§ò‡§∞' (House of Words), what does the 'house with many rooms' represent?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: The metaphor compares a word to a house with many rooms, representing the different aspects and connections of a single word. Each room in this house stands for related forms such as synonyms, antonyms, word families, and multiple meanings. Just as a physical house holds many interconnected rooms under one roof, a word has many dimensions of meaning and connections to other words. Understanding this concept helps students explore the rich vocabulary of the Marathi language holistically.
keyPoints: The metaphor compares a word to a house with many rooms.
The 'rooms' represent synonyms, antonyms, and multiple meanings.
It illustrates how one word is connected to many other words.
This holistic view helps build a strong and rich Marathi vocabulary.

longAnswers.question: Explain the concept of '‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§ï‡•Å‡§ü‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¨' (Word Family) with a suitable example.
longAnswers.modelAnswer: A word family (‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§ï‡•Å‡§ü‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¨) is a group of words that are related because they all originate from the same root word (‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≥ ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶). Just like a human family has relatives, a word family has many derived forms sharing a core meaning. For example, from the root word '‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ' (knowledge), we get a whole family of words like '‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä' (student), '‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ø' (school), and '‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®' (scholar). Understanding word families helps students easily guess the meanings of new and unfamiliar words.
keyPoints: A word family consists of words derived from the same root word.
Words in a family share a core conceptual meaning.
Recognizing root words is an effective strategy to expand vocabulary.

longAnswers.question: What are '‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶' (Words with Multiple Meanings)? Give an example.
longAnswers.modelAnswer: '‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶' are single words that possess multiple, completely different meanings depending on the context in which they are used. The word '‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§ï' means many, and '‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•' means meaning. For instance, the word '‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞' can mean an 'arrow' in one context, but it can also mean a 'riverbank' in another. Students must carefully read the entire sentence to understand the correct meaning intended by the author.
keyPoints: ‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶ are single words with multiple different meanings.
The context of the sentence determines the intended meaning.
An example is '‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞', meaning both 'arrow' and 'riverbank'.
Another example is '‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•', meaning both 'definition' and 'wealth'.
